title: Protocol to induce de novo lipid droplets in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
The protocol describes the strategy for generating conditional yeast mutants in which it can produce de novo LDs. We detail the description of how to perform gene KO using a marker rescue strategy, method to introduce GAL1 promoter at endogenous locus upstream of ARE1, and how to engineer C-terminally tagged ERG6-mCherry fusion driven by its endogenous promoter. Thus, we generated yeast strain GAL-ARE1 lro1Δ dga1Δ are2Δ ERG6-mCherry (3Δ GAL-ARE1 Erg6-mCherry). Similar strategy can construct any of the acyltransferase under galactose inducible promoter.
Transformation of gene KO cassette
Timing: 6–7 days
This step describes the transformation of wild-type (BY4741) yeast strain with gene KO cassette using Lithium Acetate (LiAc) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A). Perform gene KO sequentially to obtain the triple acyltransferase yeast mutant (lro1Δ dga1Δ are2Δ) by utilizing auxotrophic marker rescue strategy using Cre recombinase after successful deletion of every gene deletion.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3150-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Homologous recombination of gene KO cassette and PCR validation of positive clones
(A) KO cassette transformation. Cartoon depicting homologous recombination between loxP-HIS5-loxP cassette and the upstream and downstream region of ARE2 gene to obtain a successful integration for gene KO cassette.
(B and C) Validation of KO by colony PCR. B) Illustration showing the binding sites of internal and external control primers for validation of positive recombinants by colony PCR. (C) Separation of PCR amplified product on 1% agarose gel to confirm the correct clone containing the desired KO.
Streak wild-type yeast strain (BY4741) on a fresh YPD plate and incubate for 2 days at 30°C.
Culture the strain in 10 mL of YPD media in a 50 mL tube for 16 h at 30°C with constant shaking at 200 rpm.

Next morning, measure the OD600 using a spectrophotometer and dilute the cells to OD600 0.15 and grow until mid-log phase until it reaches OD600 1.
Harvest the cells at 600 × g for 5 min and wash with 20 mL sterile H2O.
Centrifuge the cells at 600 × g for 5 min and wash again with 20 mL 1X TE.
Spin the cells at 600 g for 5 min and gently resuspend the pellet in 10 mL 1X LiAc solution and centrifuge again at 400 × g for 4 min.
Pour off the supernatant, gently resuspend the pellet in 1 mL LiAc solution and incubate the cells at 30°C for 30 min so that they become competent.
While cells are being incubated, boil herring sperm DNA at 95°C for 10 min and keep on ice until use.
Add reagents in the sequential manner in a sterile 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
60–70 μL of competent yeast cells.
10 μL herring sperm DNA (ice cold).
5–10 μg of KO cassette (except in control tube, add the corresponding amount of water in control).
Gently mix and incubate at 30°C for 30 min.
Add 0.7 mL Polyethylene glycol (PEG) solution, mix by gentle pipetting or tapping, and incubate for 45 min at 25°C.
Critical: Resuspend the cells gently by pipetting carefully, and avoid any shearing force, as this will reduce the transformation efficiency.
Heat shock the cells for 12 min in water bath or dry bath at 42°C and put the tubes on ice for 5 min.
Centrifuge at 600 × g for 4 min.
Carefully remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet by adding 200 μL of sterile water.
Spread the cells on SC-HIS plate using sterile glass spreader.
Incubate the plates upside down at 30°C for 3–4 days for colonies to appear.

Re-streak isolated 10–15 colonies on new SC-HIS plate and incubate at 30°C for 2 days.
Colony screening for verification of positive recombinants
Timing: 3–5 h
Isolation of genomic DNA (template for colony PCR).
Resuspend the single yeast colony or a patch mimicking a large single colony from the re-streaks in 100 μL of LiAc-SDS solution (see materials and methods).
Vortex vigorously at high speed, and incubate at 70°C in dry bath for 10 min.
Add 300 μL of absolute ethanol to the sample for DNA precipitation, vortex and collect the DNA by centrifugation at 15,000 × g for 3 min.
Remove supernatant and wash the pellet with 500 μL of 70% ethanol.
Carefully remove the supernatant and let the pellet dry at 37°C until all the ethanol has evaporated.
Add 50 μL of sterile water and vortex to dissolve the pellet.
Centrifuge at 15,000 × g for 1 min to pellet down the cell debris, use 1 μL of the supernatant as template for setting up the PCR reaction.
Set up 50 μL reaction for colony PCR using the primers listed in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]. Yeast genomic DNA serves as the template for the colony PCR (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B and 2C). PCR components and cycle condition as given in Tables 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl7] and 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl8], respectively.

Note: Annealing temperature can be calculated by New England Biolabs (NEB) tm calculator using primer sequences given in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
Run the PCR product on 1% agarose gel to observe the desired product size (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Re-streak at least two positive clones of each of the newly constructed yeast strain on either selective SC-HIS or YPD plates.
Pause point: Make a glycerol stock (25% final concentration) of the positive clones and store at ‒80°C.
Cre mediated recombination of loxP sites
Timing: 8–10 days

Perform marker rescue for sequential gene deletion by excising the auxotrophic HIS5 marker integrated at ARE2 locus by expressing Cre recombinase from a GAL inducible plasmid pSH47 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3150-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Schematics of marker rescue strategy
Illustration showing step-by-step procedure of marker rescue. Expression of Cre-recombinase on a plasmid pSH47 driven by GAL1 promoter by culturing in the presence of galactose media for 2 h results in recombination between the two loxP sites. Therefore, HIS5 selection marker gets excised, leaving only one loxP site. Cells are plated on non-selective media, replica plated onto SC-HIS and SC + All. The clones that grow on SC + All but do not grow on SC-HIS are picked, streaked on YPD, and selected on plates containing 5-FOA to cure the plasmid pSH47. Clones that grow on 5-FOA are streaked onto SC-URA and YPD to confirm the loss of URA containing plasmid. Hence, the strain obtained is a clean KO.
Transform the plasmid pSH47 (URA selection marker) expressing Cre recombinase in the are2Δ KO strain using transformation protocol as described in the previous section and plate on SC-URA.
After 2–3 days colonies will appear. Pick a bunch of 4–6 colonies, resuspend in 2 mL of YP-Galactose media, and culture for 2 h at 30°C with constant shaking at 200 rpm to induce the expression of Cre recombinase.
Plate 25 μL on the SC + ALL plates and incubate at 30°C for 2 days.
Note: Plating too much of cells can cause overcrowding of colonies. To get isolated colonies, plate less volume on SC + ALL containing plates.

Pick 20–30 individual colonies for replica plating by resuspending in 80 μL of SC + All media in a 96 well microtiter plate, and spotting 5 μL of the same colony on SC + ALL and SC-HIS plates.
Incubate the plates upside down for 2–3 days at 30°C.
Note: One can use 48 well spotter for replica plating. Orientation of both plates needs to be marked and identical spots on SC + ALL and SC-HIS need to be denoted with the same number. A clone that grows on SC + ALL but does not grow on SC-HIS is the correct clone as it has lost the HIS5 cassette.
Streak two positive clones from SC + ALL onto YPD plates for 24–48 h at 30°C.
To cure the plasmid pSH47 with URA selection marker, streak the clone that has lost HIS5 marker onto SC + ALL plates containing or lacking 5-FOA.
Yeast URA- cells will grow on 5-FOA, whereas URA+ cells will die due to buildup of toxic products in the presence of 5-FOA.
Clones that survive are the ones that have lost the plasmid pSH47.
To confirm URA- phenotype, yeast strains need to be streaked on plates containing SC-URA and SC + ALL by replica plating.
Pick the positive clones from SC + ALL plates and streak on a new non-selective plate.
Perform subsequent gene deletion using the same HIS5 auxotrophic marker to generate double or a triple yeast mutant lro1Δ dga1Δ are2Δ ARE1 (3ΔKO).
After final marker rescue, HIS5 would be free for subsequent usage.
Strategy to insert galactose inducible promoter upstream of ARE1
Timing: 3–5 days
Next, we perform insertion of galactose inducible promoter, GAL1 upstream of ARE1 gene to regulate transcriptional activation of SE acyltransferase ARE1 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3150-Fig4.jpg

Figure 4. Integration of GAL1 promoter upstream of ARE1 by homologous recombination
(A) Transformation of GAL1 insertion cassette. Illustration depicting the process of homologous recombination for insertion of GAL1 promoter upstream of ARE1 gene.
(B) Colony PCR. Verification of positive clones by performing colony PCR using forward and reverse primers shown in blue.
Culture yeast 3ΔKO cells, lro1Δ dga1Δ are2Δ ARE1 in YPD media at 30°C for 16 h with constant shaking at 200 rpm.
Perform yeast transformation as described in the previous section using GAL1-HIS5 cassette to insert GAL1 promoter upstream of ARE1 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
Note: Higher amount of cassette may be required for GAL1 promoter insertion
Incubate cells for 2–3 days at 30°C.
Perform colony PCR as described in the previous section using control primers listed in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Streak two positive clones of GAL1-ARE1 dga1Δ lro1Δ are2Δ (3Δ ARE1) on either SC-HIS or YPD plate for subsequent analysis of induction of lipid droplet formation.
C-terminal tagging of lipid droplet marker protein Erg6
Timing: 3–5 days
Next, we generate Erg6-mCherry fusion at its endogenous locus, to visualize newly formed LDs inside cells (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3150-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Generation of ERG6-mCherry fusion protein
(A) Schematics of fusion between ERG6 and mCherry at C-terminus. Illustration depicting the process of homologous recombination for insertion of mCherry-URA cassette at C-terminus of ERG6 excluding the stop codon.
(B) Colony PCR. Validation of positive clones by performing colony PCR using forward and reverse primers shown in magenta.
Culture inducible yeast mutant GAL1-ARE1 dga1Δ lro1Δ are2Δ (3Δ ARE1) in YPD media for 16 h at 30°C with constant shaking at 200 rpm.
Transform the C-terminal tagging cassette, ERG6-mCherry-URA, into 3Δ GAL1-ARE1 strain following the transformation protocol described in the previous section (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).

Note: Higher amount of cassette may be required for successful C-terminal tagging.
Plate the cells on SC-URA plates.
Incubate cells for 2–3 days at 30°C.
Screen and verify the correct integration of ERG6-mCherry-URA cassette by performing colony PCR using control primers mentioned in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Streak two positive clones of GAL1-ARE1 dga1Δ lro1Δ are2Δ ERG6-mCherry on either SC-URA or YPD plate for subsequent analysis of induction of lipid droplet formation.
De novo induction of lipid droplet biogenesis
Timing: 1 day
Production of de novo SE-only LDs by induction of yeast acyltransferase ARE1 using galactose inducible promoter, GAL1 to promote the formation of SE containing nascent LDs (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3150-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Induction of de novo lipid droplets containing either STE or TAG
(A) Cartoon depicting production of de novo LDs in yeast cells. Inducible yeast mutant cells when shifted from raffinose media to galactose containing media results in transcriptional induction of acyltransferase that catalyzes neutral lipid synthesis and production of de novo LDs.
(B) Induction of de novo STE-only droplets. Yeast cells of the indicated genotype were cultured in raffinose containing media and transferred to galactose for the indicated time. Cells were stained with BODIPY and visualized by fluorescence microscopy. White arrowheads denote colocalization between BODIPY stained LDs and Erg6. Scale bar: 5 μm.
(C) Induction of de novo TAG-only droplets. Conditional yeast mutants of the indicated genotype were cultured in raffinose containing media and transferred to galactose for the indicated time. Samples were withdrawn, stained with BODIPY, and imaged by fluorescence microscopy. White arrowheads denote colocalization between BODIPY stained LDs with Erg6. Scale bar: 5 μm.

(D) Quantification of LDs. Quantitative analysis of number of LDs formed per cell when cells are stimulated to produce de novo droplets containing either STE-only or TAG-only neutral lipids. Data represent mean +/- SD, n > 50 cells.
Inoculate a patch of GAL1-ARE1 dga1Δ lro1Δ are2Δ ERG6-mCherry strain in 10 mL YP-Raffinose media for 16 h in an incubator at 30°C, with constant shaking at 200 rpm.
Next morning, measure the OD600 using a spectrophotometer and dilute the cells corresponding to 10 OD600 units in a 50 mL culture tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 600 × g for 4 min at 25°C, discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 10 mL YP-Galactose media, and culture the cells at 30°C, with constant shaking at 200 rpm.
Withdraw ∼ 1 mL of sample at 0-, 2-, and 5-h time point and proceed with staining with BODIPY (493/503), a neutral lipid dye to stain LDs (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Procedure for BODIPY (493/503) staining:
Add 1 μL of BOIDPY (1 mg/mL) to have a final concentration of 1 μg/mL in the medium.
Stain the cells at 25°C for 2–5 min in dark.
Spin down cells at 600 × g for 2 min and wash twice with 500 μL of fatty acid free BSA (50 μM) dissolved in 1X PBS and once with 500 μL of 1X PBS.
Spin down, remove the supernatant and resuspend the cells in residual PBS or 50 μL of 1X PBS.
Put 0.5–1 μL of cells on glass slide add place a coverslip on top of the sample. Remove any excess media by gently tapping the glass slide-sample-cover slip sandwich upside down on a tissue paper.
Seal the edges of the cover slip using nail polish to prevent quick drying of samples.
Observe the slide under a fluorescence microscope.

Visualize colocalization between BODIPY stained puncta and LD marker Erg6-mCherry using Alexa Fluor 488 and Alexa Fluor 568 excitation filters respectively (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Take images from several field of view for quantification.
Perform quantification of LDs from 50‒100 cells in duplicates.
Calculate the number of LDs/cell and plot a graph using GraphPad Prism or Microsoft Excel (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B and 6D).
Note: Use XY plot with single values in X-axis and 2 values in Y axis (duplicates) for SD/mean calculation in GraphPad Prism.
